intro: Sida sampaiana, commonly known as the Brazilian mallow, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is characterized by its broad, heart-shaped leaves and produces small, pale pink or white flowers. The plant belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes other well-known species like cotton and hibiscus. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along riverbanks. Sida sampaiana is valued for its ornamental appeal and has been used in traditional medicine for various purposes.
